subject: Technology
title: Prosthetic Limbs: From Wooden Legs to Mind Control
description: A quick, practical guide to Prosthetic Limbs: From Wooden Legs to Mind Control.

hook.text: Modern prosthetic hands can be controlled by thought. Sensors read muscle signals and translate them into finger movements.

buildup.text: Prosthetics evolved from wooden pegs to mechanical hooks to computerized limbs with dozens of sensors.

discovery.text: Myoelectric prosthetics detect electrical signals from remaining muscles. Think about closing your hand and the prosthetic closes.

twist.text: Advanced prosthetics can cost over $100,000 and aren't always covered by insurance, keeping them from those who need them most.

climax.text: 3D printing is creating affordable prosthetics for under $50 in developing countries, democratizing this life-changing technology.

punchline.text: A 3D-printed hand costs $50. A mind-controlled one costs $100,000.

quiz.question: How do myoelectric prosthetics work?
options: They detect electrical signals from remaining muscles to control movements
